article.title: Maximum local quantum covariances as quantifiers of two-sided quantum correlations beyond entanglement

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 compares the quantum f-correlation of two-qubit states before (horizontal axis) and after (vertical axis) being passed through random local unital channels. What does the presence of points above the solid gray line signify?
choices: The quantum f-correlations are always monotonically non-increasing under local unital channels.
The quantum f-correlations can increase under some local unital channels, violating the desired monotonicity property.
The quantum f-correlations are always zero for states that have passed through a local unital channel.
The choice of Wigner-Yanase skew information for the analysis is inappropriate for demonstrating the behaviour of quantum f-correlations under local unital channels.

multiple_choice_question.text: Formula (1) defines a specific type of bipartite quantum state. What type of state does this formula represent?
Formula (33) presents an alternative definition for a specific instance of metric-adjusted f-correlation. What is the key advantage of this definition, particularly for thermal equilibrium states?
choices: It requires full tomographic reconstruction of the state, which is easily achievable for large systems.
It quantifies only the classical contribution to the covariance, neglecting the quantum contribution.
It relies solely on measurable quantities, avoiding the need for complex state reconstruction, especially beneficial for large systems.
It highlights the equivalence between classical and quantum statistical mechanics in quantifying correlations.

multiple_choice_question.text: Formula (35) proposes a refined definition of two-sided quantum correlations. What is the primary motivation for introducing this modified definition?
choices: To demonstrate that the original definition is fundamentally flawed and cannot quantify quantum correlations accurately.
To simplify the calculation of quantum f-correlations by reducing the complexity of the optimization problem.
To ensure that the quantity remains invariant regardless of the size of the considered multipartite system, resolving inconsistencies.
To confirm that two-sided quantum correlations are always greater than entanglement, establishing a clear hierarchy.
